newsitem.title: UK: UK grain export on fast track, but trade cautious.
newsitem.headline: UK grain export on fast track, but trade cautious.

text.p: Clelia Oziel
UK grain exports got off to a fast start this season but traders suspect the pace of sales may not keep up with a bumper harvest.
Recent trade estimates have put wheat (mainly feed) shipments at between 750,000-800,000 tonnes by the end of September -- virtually a month after the harvest began.
According to one analyst, wheat sales up to end-September could have even amounted to 900,000 tonnes, mostly to other European destinations.
This compares with 3.054 million tonnes exported in the whole of the 1995/96 season (July/June).
Traders said three big vessels of 25,000 tonnes each had been loaded with barley destined for Saudi Arabia and more was in the pipeline to cover part of a 1.4 million tonnes sale.
"I think between October and November some 400,000 tonnes will have been shipped to Saudi Arabia," said one trader.
Barley shipments reached only 1.32 million tonnes last season.

But the belief among traders that grain availability this year will outstrip demand somewhat takes the shine off the early export picture. "The figures are fairly impressive but we're not getting over-excited," said one trader. "At the end of the day, it's the end-year surplus that counts."
The European Union (EU) stepped up its export awards at weekly tenders, but traders say larger tonnages must be allowed to avoid a potential dip in prices.
The Home-Grown Cereals Authority (HGCA) has estimated the surplus wheat to be slated for export this this season at 4.5-5 million tonnes and barley at 2-2.5 million tonnes.

The HGCA's calculation was based on a projected wheat harvest of 15.75 million tonnes and barley of 7.8 million. It then set aside combined commercial stocks for wheat and barley of 2.5 million tonnes.
"We had a pretty good start to exports," said Steve Thornhill, head of marketing and economics at the HGCA. "But 4.5 million is massive. The pace of exports needs to keep going."
The most active destinations for UK wheat were Italy and Spain, which, despite a good harvest this year, continued to rely on imports while farmers sit on stocks in the hope that prices will recover.
Spain was a good buyer mainly because its lousy delivery system made it hard to compensate regional supply differences, traders said.
UK shippers also clinched deals this year with Poland, Germany, Tunisia and northern France.
But order books were beginning to dry up. One trader said orders "were next to nothing" from November onwards.
HGCA's Thornhill said UK exporters would need to maintain price competitiveness to prevent large surpluses.
As wheat prices decline towards intervention in other European countries, British prices would need to slide even further as there is no intervention on feed wheat in the UK.

"This (exports) will largely depend on a continued flow of ex-farm sales onto the market, since although post-harvest marketings have been high, pre-harvest sales were well below those of the past seasons,"the HGCA in its latest weekly report.
Supplies will be further inflated by large carryover stocks from last year. At end-June stocks of wheat are estimated at 750,000 tonnes while barley was up at 130,000 tonnes.
-- Clelia Oziel, London Newsroom +44 171 542 8072
